title: Python- Virtual Environments
text:
Python virtual enviornments have many use cases for developing. Many of the benefits come from version control between the host development machine and the target deployment environment.
Imagine that you are running multiple scripts on the same machine, which require different versions of python modules. ie. my_script_1.py -> requires requests<2.20.0 my_script_2.py -> requires requests>=2.30.0
For whatever reason you have to run two seperate version on the same host.. This simply does not work without virtual environments, or venv for short.
A venv is typically tied to a working directory. ie.
mainy.py
my_data.json
venv
The venv is a directory that contains all of the necessary binaries to run

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: About
text:
This wiki is managed by Garrison LeRock via Quarto and Github Pages. The public repo can be found here.
Most of the articles found here are what I might use on a day-to-day basis. When I forget a certain detail it’s nice to have it documented and easily referenceable.

title: Markdown Cheat Sheet
text:
Thanks for visiting The Markdown Guide!
This Markdown cheat sheet provides a quick overview of all the Markdown syntax elements. It can’t cover every edge case, so if you need more information about any of these elements, refer to the reference guides for basic syntax and extended syntax.


These are the elements outlined in John Gruber’s original design document. All Markdown applications support these elements.

title: Markdown Cheat Sheet
text: These are the elements outlined in John Gruber’s original design document. All Markdown applications support these elements.

title: SSH keys - Useful Information
text:
Intro
As a developer you will typically use SSH keys for pushing/pulling code on a remote repo. You will need to generate a public and private key locally on your machine, and then upload your public key to your repo settings. Typically you will sign your private key (with a unique password) that only you know.


Useful Information
You can generate a new SSH key on your local linux machine with this command.
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"
If you have multiple Keys to use for various remote repos… for example Github and GitLab, or maybe one for your company’s GitHub, and another for your private GitHub, you can update the config file in the .ssh directory to point to various keys.

Create the config file is it doesn’t exist touch ~/.ssh/config
Edit the file nano ~/.ssh/config
Here is an example for when you might have 3 accounts

# github account
Host github.com
HostName github.com
PreferredAuthentications publickey
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_myaccount_github

# gitlab account
Host gitlab.com
HostName gitlab.com
PreferredAuthentications publickey
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_myaccount_gitlab

# gitlab company account
Host gitlab.my_company.com
HostName gitlab.my_company.com
PreferredAuthentications publickey
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_mycompanyaccount_gitlab

title: AWS - API Gateway
text:
What Is It?
A service that allows you to expose your compute resources and other services to the internet or interanl VPC. There are a number of security controls that are availble in APIGW that can be used to secure your compute.

title: Git - Cheat Sheet
text:
Here are some useful Git commands that are used


Start a new git envionment in your current working directory git init
Connect your current git environment/directory to an upstream remote directory (ie. github/gitlab) git remote add origin [url]
Configure user info git config --global user.name "[name]" git config --global user.email "[email address]"
List current local branches git branch
Create a new local branch git branch [name]
Switch to another branch git switch [name]
Switch to a new branch git switch -c [name]
Create and switch to new branch, and move any changes to git branch -m [name]



Save local changes in current directory to a branch git add .
Save specific files to branch git add [name of files] Also supports wildcards, for example git add *.py

Switch to another branch git switch [name]

Create and switch to new branch, and move any changes to git branch -m [name]

title: Git - Cheat Sheet
text:
